reviewText:
Phil Broker (Jason Statham) is a former NARC who must now lay low due to getting the son of a crime boss killed. He is living in Louisiana which allows them to use a better soundtrack and crazy characters. His wife has passed on, he has a daughter Maddy (Izabela Vidovic) and a wanna be formulaic relationship with school counselor Susan Hatch(Rachelle Lefevre). He draws attention to himself while trying to live with a low profile, attention that endangers the life of both him and his daughter.

As art imitates life, James Franco plays the crazy bad guy and Winona Ryder his trashy girlfriend.

This is one of the better Statham films I have seen. It includes the usual tough guy talk, fighting, killings, chase scenes, and explosions. It also includes a colorful support cast with Kate Bosworth and Marcus Hester as realistic people. Bosworth was a pistol.

Worth seeing for fans of action films.

Parental Guide: F-bomb, garage sex, no nudity. Deals with meth manufacture and use.

According to English journalist Christopher Booker, there are only seven basic plots, but screenwriter Sylvester Stallone ("Rambo" and "Rocky") uses my favorite one (Overcoming the Monster). He gives us someone to root for and then puts that individual in jeopardy.

After establishing our hero's credibility as an undercover agent for an alphabet soup of agencies, this non-stop actioner gets started with a simple little case of grade-school bullying which results in a fist fight; the families quickly escalate the situation and from there on, the action rarely lets up.

We watch:
  * Jason Statham ("The Transporter") A mystified local cop thinks maybe Phil Broker is in the Witness Protection Program...or something. He clearly is NOT a run-of-the-mill local yokel in the small Southern hamlet where he and his daughter have settled.
  * Izabela Vidovic (Lots of TV) is his daughter Maddy, who, miracle of miracles, does NOT trip and fall when being chased, is resourceful and clever, and knows how to stick up for herself.
  * James Franco ("Oz the Great and Powerful") is Gator, a down-home bad boy with a hi-tech meth lab that will be his ticket to the big time.
  * Kate Bosworth ("Win a Date with Tad Hamilton!") is his sister, furious over that playground incident and dead set on revenge.
  * Wynona Ryder ("The Iceman") is Sheryl Mott, a foul-mouthed barmaid; she delivers a file to a powerful man who needs it, then she watches the whole violent catastrophe unfold.

This has a richly deserved R rating, so expect lots of profanity, broken bones and torture, many intervals of gunfire and drug use along with some highly satisfying blowie uppie stuff. However, I hope you noticed that I said in the first paragraph "Overcoming the Monster" so that means a happy ending! Whew...

I didn't like this movie, but I'm giving it three stars because it's okay for what it is. It's a Sylvester Stallone tough guy fantasy.

When I saw a clip of this movie, I thought it might be an action film with some nice father/daughter touches. But it was far more focused on beating up and killing rednecks and bikers. The hero, Broker, is laughably tough. It doesn't matter how many guys Broker is fighting, or how many guns the bad guys have, or if Broker is tied up. He'll always win and he'll never get hurt too much.

It's sort of interesting to see Winona Ryder playing the role of a skank (that's how people refer to her in the movie). This movie isn't flattering to small, bucolic towns in Louisiana. There are violent "feuds" that apparently are pretty common. As the gorgeous schoolteacher said, the town is "a bit like Appalachia and people around here can do foolish things." The sheriff in the town - who isn't an evil character - allows one of his snitches (James Franco) to operate a large meth lab. It's a far cry from Sheriff Andy Taylor in Mayberry.

Here's something odd: The small town in which this movie takes place, Rayville, is almost three-quarters African American, but in this movie there is only one African American character. He's a good guy, by the way. In the school that the daughter attends, there are only white kids. From what I could find out from a little research, none of the filming took place in Rayville. It would be interesting to know why they decided to pick Rayville, an actual town, for the setting of this movie, when none of the filming took place there.

The end of the film confused me. Broker visits the prison to talk to the drug boss who ordered the hit on him and his daughter. He tells him, with a smile, that he'll be waiting for him when he gets out. This doesn't make sense for two reasons. First, even if the drug boss is in jail, he can order more hits on Broker and his daughter. Broker makes no effort to change his name or hide his identify, and he plans to stay in the same house and the same town, where he and his daughter will be an easy target. Broker is essentially declaring open war on the drug boss and his small army, and I don't care how tough the guy is, he's putting his daughter at great risk. The daughter is completely unprotected at the school she attends.

Second, why would the drug boss have any chance of getting out of jail? He's not in jail just on major drug charges. During the drug bust where he gets arrested, at the beginning of the movie, many law enforcement officers were killed. The drug boss was shooting along with the rest of his gang, so he should have a life sentence. Well, the obvious answer is that they wanted to leave it open for a sequel and they need the drug boss to get out of jail for the final showdown. I guess you could say there's a feud between Broker and the drug boss. If they make a sequel I might watch it if the gorgeous schoolteacher is in it (Rachel Lefevre).

Young Izabela Vidovic as Statham's daughter is a study in pint-sized maturity, and is a screen natural.

Statham stars as a dad with a daughter, he an ex-DEA agent whos laying low because he offed the wrong bad guys kid.  His daughter, who knows how to defend herself, beats up one of the local bullies who is bullying her.  This sets off a chain reaction where the bullys mom (a strung out and nettery Kate Bosworth who does a great job here) gets her family to tangle JayStay up and cause them lots of problems, mainly by way of her drug dealing backwater bayou brother (played by a sketchy James Franco).  Franco is in no wise a physical match for JayStay and fortunately the movie doesnt try to make us think he is.  Instead Francos connections with the local bad guys and to the crime family that Statham is trying to avoid brings down all of the heat on cueballs head.  The story is a basic one, but the characters are more fleshed out than one might expect, the acting is pretty good, and the narrative manages to keep the tension in place. Homefront may not break new ground, but Jason Stathams new film knows what it is doing, with lots of action and one-liners like Whatever you're thinking, rethink it. Helmed by Gary Fleder (whose previous works as director includes Runaway Jury Kiss the Girls and Dont Say a Word), Homefront is a slick action thriller even though you have to ignore its totally predictable and implausible storyline.

Jason Statham is a retired DEA agent Phil Broker, who decides to settle in a quiet Southern town with his 10-year-old daughter Maddy (Izabela Vidovic). But soon Phil gets entangled with a local drug dealer named Gator (James Franco). The chain of events leading up to the confrontation between Phil and Gator is unbelievable, but is done with enough fight scenes to keep the film interesting.

Based on a Chuck Logan novel and adapted for screen by Sylvester Stallone (who also co-produced), Homefront slightly reminds us of the old-school action movies in the 80s. I am not fully convinced of the characters and the storyline here, and the climax is pretty muddled, but all in all Homefront is an engaging ride.

All of the characters are tropes:  the highly skilled, veteran policeman just trying to live a quiet life (but failing), the innocent daughter, the attractive female schoolteacher, the small town hicks fueled by vendetta, addicted drug addicts, a small scale drug dealer in over his head, a violent biker gang, and a vengeful crime boss attempting to exact revenge from behind bars.

Look, Homefront isn't anything special.  It's really nothing new but, to its credit, it does what it does competently.  The acting is fairly good, the film looks nice (and even has a unique scene transition approach where it shows flashes of the upcoming scene interspersed into the concluding moments of the preceding scene).  The first half is eminently watchable, although not intellectually stimulating.

The second half struggles somewhat.  It has the same pros in its favor as in the first half, but in the last half the viewer is able to see the seams holding everything together too clearly; the movie just becomes too predictable.  It also blunders into mimicking the plot of the movie Taken, albeit taking place here in a rural American neighborhood rather than across international venues.

One aspect of the film that is both implausible and somewhat laughable is how the lead protagonist has such bad luck that he keeps stumbling into meth baking operations--first in his undercover job, then "by chance" as a private citizen.  The plot needs this to be the case so that it can tie the two together and have his past come back to haunt him, but it stretches credibility.

So it is what it is.  I'm not going to tear it down.  Viewed on its own terms, it's fine.

Phil Broker (Statham) becomes disillusioned when his fellow agents gun down an already shot son of a drug kingpin.  Broker had infiltrated the gang and had set up the bust.  Sitting at home hoping her daddy would come back, I guess, was Broker's 10 year old daughter Maddy (Izabela Vidovic).

Broker decides to pull the plug on his career and retire(?)to Louisiana redneck country.  He buys and nice little house off a remote road so that Maddy can ride her horse and fish in a pond.  Well, wouldn't you know, the little town is flush with methamphetamine dealers and the big fish in this little pond is a guy named Gator Bodine (stop laughing).  Gator (James Franco) has the usual cadre of numbskulls working for him.  He's also the supplier to his `Twiggy'-thin tweaker sister, Cassie played by a you-have-to-look-twice Kate Bosworth.

When Maddy pummels a bully in the playground, Broker is threatened by the boy's parents who just happened to be Cassie and her Neanderthal hubby Jimmy (Marcus Hester).  That doesn't go so well for Jimmy, so now Broker is a marked man for revenge.  But Broker is no ordinary bloke.  He's...well, he's Jason Statham.  So how do you think this is all going to go down?  Yep, you're right.  Even when Gator calls in the cavalry - a score of biker goons - they are no match for our hero.

Don't get me wrong, I actually like Jason Statham and I love to see him kick evil-doer butt, but come on.  Give the guy something to work with.  Finally, I got a chuckle out of seeing poor Winona Ryder play a strung out biker slut and sometime Gator plaything.  Brother.  I suspect this film will have some appeal to Statham fans, no matter how bad the movie is, so watch it, if you must, on Blu ray.

It is very loud and it shut down my not quite warmed up amp trying to save my speakers.  The movie isn't all shootouts and bar fights however.  There are quiet moments between Broker and Maddy that are clear and distinct.  The surrounds are often brought into play, especially during the action sequences.  Subtitles are available in English SDH, Spanish and French.  Extras are few; some deleted scenes, an extended ending and a promo.

How is it that Jason Statham has such a hard time getting good roles? People like him. He's about as good an action star as his contemporaries. Even this outing, while marginally better than some of his other films, falls short.

Here's the scoop. Statham plays a DEA agent who retires after a particularly nasty, violent sting and moves with his daughter to northern Louisiana where he hopes to live a quiet life. Fat chance. of that happening. It seems Meth is a big deal in those parts and events conspire to draw him into a situation he was trying to leave behind.

Sylvester Stallone wrote the script which was based on a novel. I haven't read the source so I don't know how far the script strayed, but it just wasn't that good. Things start off really well. The opening, partially failed sting. The switch to the more peaceful setting, as we watch his young daughter turn the tables on the bully, play well. But then things head south. The set-up to get the heat turned up held too much coincidence for my liking. That Winona Ryder agreed to such a small, sketchy role was curious. I kept figuring her part would escalate as the movie progressed. That it didn't helped to drag things down. I'm not a huge James Franco fan but this is about as good as I've seen him. Jason Statham didn't move out of his comfort zone but we really don't want/expect him to. There are some other established actors throughout that do well with what they're given.

Director Gary Fleder did a decent job here. Nice attention is paid to the locations and he draws some good performances out of people. I also liked Mark Isham's music score. It added flavor without making itself too conspicuous. To me this failed at the script level. The longer it ran the worse it got. This isn't a bad watch but it's a typical guy flick that doesn't manage to rise above the fray.

When you combine Action with Drama, you had better have a damn good story to go along with the tremendous fight scenes and wild chases, or else you get a film that falls flat. We all know that at this point, Jason Statham is the best Action star you could have, but the jury was out on how effect he could be in a more dramatic role. In Home Front, Statham plays a retired undercover D.E.A. agent, who has recently become a single father. He and his daughter have moved from the big city to the small town, which his late wife called home, in the hopes of building a better life. Everything was going as planned until his daughter, stood up to a bully at school, and embarrassed the son of one the towns most influential families. The simple misunderstanding between children quickly escalates into an all out war, which will force Statham to use everything he learned in the D.E.A. to protect his daughter and his new home. Once again, Jason Statham was terrific in this film. It is mind boggling and seems to be impossible, but every film this man does is better than the one before it. He is on a winning streak, the likes of which I have never seen. Statham was terrific, but oddly, he's paired with an actor who doesn't have much experience playing the bad guy and it showed. James Franco plays Gator Bodine, a small time hood and drug trafficker, who goes after Statham with everything he's got, the only problem is, Bodine really isn't that bad a guy. In fact, when Franco starts cursing and playing all tough, it's almost laughable, not to mention the fact that he doesn't have a tenth of the fighting skills that Statham has. Being that this was a big budget film, Written by Sylvester Stallone (Rocky),  Directed by Gary Fleder (Kiss The Girls, Runaway Jury), and starting the best action star in the game (Jason Statham), it's very peculiar that they would choose a bad guy, who is best known as a comedic actor. While the story was great, Franco simply can not match up with Statham at all. Homefront has almost everything you could want in a Thriller, but the lack of a strong, believable opponent, really calls into question just how believable the film is and makes it somewhat predictable.

"Homefront" is an excellent outing.  While the plot of ex-military/police retired in an out-of-the-way locale who runs into trouble from the past is not new, director Gary Fleder invests the characters in Sylvester Stallone's screenplay with depth and propels the pacing from start to finish.  The star Jason Statham turns in one of his best performances as the widower who loves his daughter and is making a new life for them.  Perhaps the surprise of the movie is Kate Bosworth who has the distinction of having been nominated as Best Actress for a Saturn Award (Science Fiction Academy) and as Worst Actress for a Razzie Award for the same film as Lois Lane in Superman Returns (2006).  She veritably steals the film.  As Cassie Bodine Klum, she is a spitfire tigress bent on backwoods retribution.  She spews insults at everyone in her way.  It is an edgy, last-nerve performance worth the price of the film.  Marcus Hester who plays the supporting role of Cassie's (Bosworth) husband, Jimmy Klum, also turns in a great performance as the backwoods husband who is both bully and coward.  Child actor Austin Craig has a great spin as the chubby bully who picks a fight with the wrong girl on the playground that ignites the fuse of action that follows.  Izabela Vidovic as Statham's daughter Maddy shows range and is a charming presence that warms the film.  James Franco does another bad guy role (reference Spider-Man 3) and combines a lethal smile with a stunning lack of character.  Rachelle Lefevre (Twilight/Under the Dome) adds some romantic potential for Statham.  Omar Benson Miller who was on CSI Miami does a great job as the handyman and loyal friend to Statham.  The deleted scenes on the DVD are interesting to show the director's choices on the final ending edit.  With such a strong cast doing top-level work, Fleder keeps the bar high and lifts this action-packed drama above the cut.  Enjoy!

Yes, there are a few flaws, but this movie is entertaining until the very end.  No slow spots.  No corny dialogue.  No forced comedy, like you see in a lot of action flops these days.

The daughter is not annoying or stupidly cute--just the opposite!  She is a character worth following.  She's believable, and that is refreshing.  Great new actress.

There is a pleasant hint of a love interest between our hero and his kid's psychologist, but no subplot that ruins everything with forced emotions and gratuitous sex just so the writers can create another pawn for the bad guys to kidnap, beat, kill, etc.  That lazy trope is avoided here.  In fact, since a relationship is hinted at, you often wonder if she is a plant for the bad guys.

This movie builds and builds and builds!  The tension hikes up logically and tragically.  The action is never over the top.  Every fight is realistic.  Every explosion is inventively induced.

The acting is superb.  Statham is an action superhero, of course, but his acting is top notch in this flick.  Frank Grillo and James Franco are two very different villains that get thrown into this mix, making for an exciting and unpredictable plot.  All because of one woman's lack of parenting skills and backwoods ignorance (Kate Bosworth plays the part perfectly).  Grillo is a frightening psycho.  Franco is a thoughtful, almost likable scumbag.

The characters change in this movie and/or they are portrayed with just enough depth that they feel realistic.  James Franco plays a more down-to-earth villain who you could definitely run into these days.  His humanity pops in and out of scenes, which is a nice touch.  His sister grows as a person.  Ryder's junkie ho is also teetering on the verge of humanity.  Believably.

The flaws?  Well, you might not agree, but . . .

1) James Franco vs. Jason Statham.  The final "battle" is kind of a letdown.  You hear so much about Franco's reputation.  It kind of felt like Robin fighting Thor.  Although, again, his character's depth is revealed.

2) The accents.  The movie can't decide if Statham's character is from Australia.  It reminds me of when they used to screw up films starring Arnold.  Likewise, Franco loses the southern accent often.  If you are portraying Southerners, keep the proper accent.  Only Statham's character's work buddy and the town sheriff keep it accurate the entire movie.

3) Long-haired Statham.  It looks so fake that I am pretty sure any MC would laugh and throw beer kegs at him.  They could have done him up better, grown out a beard, anything!  Keep him bald with a beard.  One tug on that shaggy toupee in a bar brawl and his cover is GONE.

4) Chuck Zito.  I am surprised at how much better an actor this guy is becoming.  What few may know is that he is a real deal Hell's Angel with PROBABLY a LOT of criminal experience.  He knocked out Jean Claude Van Damme in a night club.  He is a tough, frightening guy.  Why not use Zito in an epic fight scene!?!  He is a hulk of a guy with a REAL background in violence you and I can only imagine.

So . . . SEE THIS MOVIE NOW.  Is it worth buying?  Yeah, if you love Statham or action films with some thought put into them.  RECOMMENDED!!!!

Star line-up where everyone delivers. 2. While it is an "R" due to violence, there aren't any unnecessary violence, blood or offensive gestures. Somehow every scene made sense and there were no out-of-place close-ups or graphical displays. But  remember, it is an "R" because there were a lot of well placed "behind" kicking and bashing. 3. Homefront is a thriller about a man who will go to dangerous extremes to protect his family. Phil Broker (Jason Statham) is an ex-DEA agent whose desire for the quiet life has taken him, along with 10-year-old daughter Kit, to a small Louisiana town to settle down.

When Kit inadvertently precipitates a chain of clan violence, Broker must draw upon the deadly skills he hoped to keep in his past and deal with local crime lord Gator Bodine (James Franco). Bodine runs a boat-repair business thats merely a front for his lucrative meth lab, and he has the towns sheriff on the payroll.

Though its initially strange to see Franco in a villainous role, he plays it straight, with a crazed, megalomaniacal gaze that has a withering effect on everyone except Broker. As for Statham, this is standard-issue for him, as before long hes taking on the bad guys single-handedly, showing them through bloodied heads and broken appendages that crime doesnt pay.

Homefront(released Nov/13)stars,among others,Jason Statham,James Franco,Winona Ryder and Clancy Brown. This is a taut,well edited film with a screenplay by Mr. Sly Stallone that leaves little room for chaff,and gives you all the wheat you could ask for.
The story finds Statham as a DEA undercover cop who,with his colleagues,manages to take down the head of a notorious biker gang in a big drug bust. Unfortunately the biker's son dies in the take down and vengeance is now on the menu.
Fast forward two years and Statham is living on an old plantation with his soon to be 10 year old daughter;his wife having past away a few months before. He makes a living now doing house renno's. One day at school his daughter is forced to punch out a bully and he,along with the bully's parents, are summoned to the school. The bully's parents are not too happy,and in fact the mother is overly upset with Statham. Outside the father attempts to teach Statham a lesson but he is taken down in short order.
The mother is not finished yet,as she goes home and enlists the help of her brother. He happens to be the area's king pin drug maker/seller. While Statham and his daughter are out riding he enters their house and finds some incriminating files linking Statham to his DEA days and the take down of the aforementioned biker gang. Before he leaves he slashes a tire,takes their cat and leaves a now-messed up stuffed animal hanging in a tree.
The drug dealer,knowing the gang and their connections,tries to leverage a bargain with them. In exchange for the location of Statham,he wants to be given total distribution rights for his drugs in that area. The gang arrives but aren't too interested in the drug dealer's bargaining rights. They want and get the location of Statham. By now Statham has been put on the alert as to what might be coming and he and his daughter are packing to get away from their home. Before they can they are jumped and a gun fight ensues. Statham's daughter has alerted the cops by cell phone and by the time they get there Statham has all but finished them all off. However his daughter has been captured by the drug dealer's moll and she is heading back to the dealer. When she arrives back at their hideout he is none too happy that she would bring the girl with her.
When Statham realizes where his daughter may be commandeers a police car and races to the scene. Before he can get there the drug dealer's sister(the one who set his involvement in motion in the first place)has arrived. When she throws on the lights to the hideout the light bulbs,which had been previously sabotaged by Statham,explode and set the place alight. The sister struggles to take the girl from her brother and he shoots her by accident. He takes the girl in his pick up and he lets out just as Statham comes in. Statham pursues him onto a moving bridge over a river. Statham has flipped his police cruiser and as the drug dealer approaches he is still trapped. As Statham's daughter's pleads for him to let her father go,Statham becomes free. He takes down the dealer once and for all,as the police look on,on shore. The film ends as Statham and his daughter finally settle in to their new life. However Statham pays a visit to the biker he took down those many years ago,in prison. The biker is speechless as Statham tells him when he gets out,he will be waiting for him.
The film moves along very well and there are very few let ups any where,as each plot detail dove tails into the other. Mr. Stallone and Statham have become very good friends since their collaborations on the Expendables,and this movie was certainly tailor made for Statham. Statham has all his usual moves you come to expect and he even has some chance for some dramatic moments. That being said,I found that Statham seemed to be looking a little,ummm,tired...if that's the word? More times than not it seemed like he was going through the motions. But the plot and editing being what it was,nicely glossed over any weaknesses. Winona Ryder plays the drug dealers moll/girlfriend. I didn't even recognize her right off and cannot say I was particularly impressed by her acting at all. Finally I must mention Clancy Brown's nice turn as the town sheriff.
Technically speaking the film is in its original a/r of 2:40:1 and is clear and crisp. There are no extras,which I thought was somewhat of a cheat. I'm sure there must be some interview material with Mr. Stallone and Statham somewhere that could have been included.
All in all a nice dramatic piece. It is full of action and tension and Mr Stallone has written a nice screenplay,tailor made for its star.

It's Jason Statham movie time. You've read the other reviews so the plot is somewhat revealed but it doesn't relieve the pressure cooker intensity of this fabulous action thriller.  Directed by Gary Fleder who honed his craft on such up and coming titles as 'KISS THE GIRLS'-1997 and 'RUNAWAY JURY'-2003 piles on the ominous atmosphere with great set pieces. It also helps that he has a great ensemble of actors along for the ride.  James Franco plays his villainous Gator Bodine role as an intelligent misfit surrounded by a den of backwoods denizens under his drug controlled empire unfortunately the great Clancy Brown has very little to do as the sheriff on the take.  Although Jason Statham is front and center , the excellent screenplay by Sylvester Stallone based on a novel by Chuck Logan lets the female roles outshine the proceedings:  Winona Ryder is wonderful as Franco's motorcycle mama partner looking like she just walked off the set of Kurt Sutter's 'SONS OF ANARCHY'; Kate Bosworth emerges as the films scene stealer as Franco's cokehead sister who sets the plot in motion and unfortunately, Rachelle Lefevre who is shining on the Stephen King television hit 'UNDER THE DOME' goes the way of Clancy Brown as having very little to do as a possible love interest for Statham.  It is Jason's show all the way and thankfully the photography by Theo Van De Sande plays up the snap/crackle violence when it erupts. The Blu-ray is presented in a flawless 1080P widescreen transfer  although skimpy on the extras department with a 3 minute(?) behind the scenes blink or you'll miss spot and  a theatrical trailer plus trailers for other Universal releases.  In short, a superb adrenalin rouser for Statham fans.

Over the years, my strategy with Jason Statham films has changed drastically from I need to see this to Ill just wait for the movie to be released on DVD/Blu-Ray. Although Ive always loved the dramatic tension Statham brings to his violent action-thrillers, the movies themselves have become very hit or miss over the past two or three years. This resulted in me being pleasantly surprised with his last film, Redemption, and I found myself singing a similar tune after watching his latest thriller, Homefront. With a solid cast, a surprisingly tender story, and some intense action sequences, Homefront proves itself to be a worthy addition to any fan of Stathams work.

Phil Broker (Statham) is an ex-DEA agent and ex-soldier. After the passing of his wife, Broker and his daughter, Maddy (Izabela Vidovic), move to Minnesota, where they plan to start fresh. Unfortunately, after Maddy puts the school bully in his place, his parents get furious, and his mother, Cassie (Kate Bosworth), contacts her brother and drug trafficker, Gator (James Franco). What begins as a small family feud soon escalates into more as Brokers past demons come back to haunt him, and in their wake is a stream of death and destruction. With a young daughter to think about, Broker must confront these demons while avoiding unnecessary harm to those around him.

Although it may not be intentional, a major part of the story revolves around family, and learning to let go of minor differences. From the moment he steps into his new life, Broker is told by multiple peopleincluding Sheriff Keith Rodrigue (Clancy Brown) and Tito (Omar Benson Miller), Brokers friend from workthat people in town hold grudges. With the loss of his wife, Broker just wants to have a normal, comfortable living with his daughter, but this family and their grudges make his transition difficult. Originally, Gator has nothing against Broker because he doesnt know who he is, but he feels obligated to help his sister. I found that this aspect of the narrative provides some unique insight into the human psyche and how we chose to justify our actions.

The premise, while simple, manages to make itself so enjoyable because it attempts to bring a more humane element to these extremely violent situations. Similar to Redemption, the narrative never feels like a flimsy set-up used to create just another action film; there are personal differences that manage to get out of hand, and both parties are acting out due to their very different feelings towards their families. Broker is looking out for his family while Gator is acting out because of his. Their motives are different, and this is shown in the way they handle themselves individually and when they're together on-screen.

Still, a Statham flick wouldnt be a Statham flick without some crazy action sequences and some equally crazy schemes, and Homefront isn't lacking in either category. Whether Broker is taking down dudes at the gas station, or plotting on Gators safe house, Homefront is intense, its thrilling, and its a pure adrenaline rush. Part of this is accomplished through some extremely eerie music, which was composed by Mark Isham, but Homefront also manages to have some surprisingly solid cinematography, as well. The shaky cam that seems to plague 99% of all action movies is all but absent in here, and if this annoyance was present, I didn't notice it. The fight scenes may not have broken new ground, but they were essentially more or less what weve grown to love from Statham.

Finally, the performances, while not a major standout of the film, are strong when they needed to be, but they could have been better. Statham himself has characters like Broker down to a science, so he didn't really bring anything new to the table. He did excel in certain scenes, but it was more or less the same old same old, unfortunately. Similarly, Izabela Vidovic wasn't too impressive either. She managed to pull off a decent Statham impression, but the further you got in the story, the more generic her character became. The real accomplishment, for me, was Mr. James Franco. From his very first scene until the rolling of the credits, Franco was this intimidating, menacing badass, and it was so fun to watch. Every once in a while Franco receives a role that truly exemplifies his ability as an actor, and Gator is one of those roles.

Overall Score: 7.9/10 - As an action-thriller, Homefront never breaks any new ground, but that doesnt stop it from being a complete blast from start to finish. The somewhat personal narrative is woven perfectly with the action sequences, which allows the film to progress at a nice pace, and its length feels perfect for the story they are trying to tell. There were certain areas that could have been improved, but for what it is, Homefront is worth the time if you're a fan of Stathams work, or if you want to see James Franco give a stellar performance as Gator.

Here are the surprises in the movie:

(1) Sylvester Stallone wrote the script, and was one of the producers, and is personal friends with Jason Statham. So how could this be such a bad movie?  (See below.)

In a town where everyone is suspicious of all "outsiders"?  And where a major drug operation going on?  Did no one in the DEA do research on this town?

Second, Statham buys a fixer-upper, but doesn't have the sense to put video cameras and motion detectors around the property?  With today's high tech, as soon as some one stepped foot on his property his IPad would have buzzed and he would instantly see who it is.  This is a no brainier.

Third, who goes off and does not lock their front door?  And not have an internal alarm system with a 160 decibel blaster?  Nope, the bad guy just walks in the open front door and takes his time searching the place.

NOW HERE IS THE REALLY BIG PLOT CRAPOLA:  Forth: This NARC (Statham), who is in hiding, has take his files with him! I mean the files that are used in prosecuting the drug lord he busted -- and he also took his undercover file!  Pictures and all!  And guess where they are?  In the basement in cardboard boxes!  That's right, not in a safe, not hidden behind a wall, but right out in the open in the basement.  Of course the bad guy goes through the unlocked top secret boxes and discovers the real identity of Statham.  Duh.

(3) Poor Winona Ryder.  She is given first female billing, but she is really third.  What happened to her career?  She must have been desperate for cash to take this role.

In this movie, you just don't buy the fact that he is a big time -- super dangerous -- drug manufacturer in the redneck south.  He's a small skinny guy that Statham could lightly bitch slap and that would be the end of it.  Very poor casting choice.

Chuck Logan's novel has been transformed into a screenplay by Sylvester Stallone and as directed by Gary Fleder the end result is a tense, rapid paced thriller. Set in the smarmy swamplands of the Bayou, a location that adds immensely to the atmosphere of the drama, this is a film that for some reason was overlooked in the theaters (likely a timing release problem). It is full of fine ideas and is brought to life by a very strong cast of well known and not so well known but very competent actors: with Jason Statham at the helm we can be assured it will be a action packed brutal survey of crime and its manifestations.

Phil Broker Jason Statham is a former DEA agent who has gone through a crisis after his action against a biker gang went horribly wrong and it cost the life of his boss' son. He is recently widowed and is left with a 9-year-old daughter, Maddy (Izabela Vidovic), and deciding to step out of the dangerous life of a NARC agent he moves to his deceased wife's quit town for Maddy's sake. Maddy draws attention when she has a confrontation with the school bully (Austin Craig) whose parents (Marcus Hester and Kate Bosworth - in a surprisingly fine role) cause trouble setting into motion a series of events that ends in his direct confrontation with the local Meth drug lord Gator (James Franco - excellent!) whose addicted sister happens to be Kate Bosworth. Broker's past history with the biker gang also enters the arena, making matters more complex. But he has a mission in his mind to protect his daughter and he is ready to pay any cost that it demands, despite the fact that the local sheriff (Clancy Brown) is in cahoots with the Meth gang. One of Gator's kind, Cyrus (Frank Grillo) and his girlfriend, the sleazy Sheryl (Winona Rider), are brought into the picture to kill Broker, a kidnapping takes place and an attack on Gator's Meth lab ends in a whale of a combustion that only lights up the surprising final scenes.

Yes, this is a rather grisly film about a disturbing subject, but the performances by Statham, Franco, Bosworth, Ryder, Vidovic, Susan Hetch as the school psychologist and love interest, and Grillo are excellent and the supporting cast is rich in terrifying characters portrayed by a fine supporting cast. After his actions caused the death of a biker gang leader's son DEA agent Phil Broker (Statham) and his 9 year old daughter decide to move and start their life over. Things are going OK until Maddy stands up to a bully at her school. This little event starts a chain reaction that involves local drug dealer "Gator" Bodine (Franco) and brings up Phil's past that he was trying to run from. Before I start I have to admit that I am a Jason Statham fan so that may affect my review. On the other hand even though I like him he pretty much does the same movie over and over. That said this one is different from the others...for the most part. The movie makes you feel tense and on edge almost the entire time because of the fact that the daughter is in the middle of what is happening. Even though James Franco is the "bad guy" in the movie Kate Bosworth is really the one to watch. Her character is the reason I felt tense and is the scariest of all of them. The movie is very believable and the fact that nothing is too over the top makes it that much more tense. A mother upset about her son getting beat up (even though he started it) sets off a dangerous chain of events when she wants revenge. That could happen. Overall, tense and exciting, one of Statham's best. I really liked it. I give this a B+.

Let me start by saying that Jason Statham and James Franco are two of my favorite actors.  That alone is good enough to merit at least 4 stars before I even see the movie!  The fact that this was written by Sylvester Stallone might turn a few people off.  I mean, let's be honest,...he's not exactly known lately for his uber quality in movies!  HOWEVER, this one is FANTASTIC!!!!

*******WARNING,.....If you continue to read I might spoil the movie (although I will try to leave as much out as possible)!*******

The movie begins with Phil Broker (Jason Statham) as an undercover officer who has worked his way into the role of a leading man in a biker gang known as the "Outcasts".  These guys are heavy hitters in the drug trade and he has set the stage for the DEA to make the big bust.  Things go slightly wrong and the leader of the gang, Danny T (Chuck Zito) is captured while his son dies in a police shootout.  Danny T, of course, blames Brocker for the death of his son after seeing that he IS, in fact, an undercover officer.

The movie then skips ahead some time in the future (we'll say a year, give or take?).  Broker and his daughter, Maddy (Izabela Vidovic) now live in Northern Louisiana. (his wife has since passed away)  While attending school, a bully steals Maddy's hat and is quickly beaten down after she gives him, what she calls, "his two warnings".  This results in Broker getting called to school along with the bully's parents, Cassie (Kate Bosworth) and Jimmy Klum (Marcus Hester) being called in as well.

At this point, I'd like to take the time to explain just how underrated an actress I think Kate Bosworth is.  She can go from a beautiful college student (21), to this movie, playing a cracked out looking, piece of trash and pull it off flawlessly!  That's a total compliment, just to make sure.  And props to the makeup crew for being able to transform a woman like Kate into this mess and be completely believable.  Back to the review......

Cassie basically goes NUTS on Broker and demands an apology, to which Broker has none.  While leaving, she forces Jimmy to confront Broker, to absolutely no avail.  After they get home and Cassie belittles Jimmy, she calls on her brother, Gator (James Franco) to help straighten out the situation.  At this point, we've seen what type of person Gator is from an earlier scene in the movie (that was ridiculously AWESOME, by the way).  Gator sends two guys to help Broker with his supposed "attitude" only to have Broker straighten those guys out as well.  (Again,...AWESOME!)  Here we see the sheriff (Clancy Brown,....better known as CAPTAIN HADLEY from 'The Shawshank Redemption') pulling over Broker and having another "friendly" chat.  Broker decides to make piece after discovering his house was broken into (at which point, Gater discovers Broker's former identity) and heads to talk to Cassie and Jimmy.  He apologized, but doesn't realize that it's too late for them all since Gator is now intent on telling Danny T, he knows where his former "friend" is.  Gator sends Sheryl (Winona Rider) to talk with Danny's lawyer and set up a deal that will allow Gator complete distribution for the drugs he creates.  Danny T sends his best man, Cyrus (Frank Grillo) to deal with the whole situation.  Afterwards, Cyrus and crew refuse Gators offer an force Sheryl to tell them where Broker is.  Things go wrong at Broker's house and Maddy gets taken by Sheryl.  Gator is far from pleased that she'd bring a "witness" back and is about to put a stop to the situation when Cassie and Jimmy show up to talk.  While discovering what is going on, Cassie inadvertently ignites a trap that Broker had set earlier on, leaving Gator without drug organization.

In the final scene, we find Broker (being the complete badass that he is) going to the jail to personally deliver a message for Danny T.

All in all, if you want a great action movie, then this is the one for you!  Great acting and story all around!  Just a really fun movie to watch!
